intro: Graptophyllum ilicifolium, commonly known as the holly-leaved graptophyllum, is a species of flowering plant in the family Ericaceae. It is native to the southeastern United States, particularly in wetland and swampy habitats. The plant is characterized by its evergreen foliage, with leaves that are leathery and resemble those of holly. Its small, white flowers bloom in clusters and are followed by dark blue berries. Graptophyllum ilicifolium is often found in moist, acidic soils and plays a role in stabilizing wetland ecosystems.
